sn42.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā mallesu viharati uruvelakappaṁ nāma mallānaṁ nigamo.
sn42.11:1.1.ref: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town named Uruvelakappa.
sn42.11:1.1.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town named Uruvelakappa.

sn42.11:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhadrako gāmaṇi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho bhadrako gāmaṇi bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
sn42.11:1.2.ref: Then Bhadraka the village chief went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
sn42.11:1.2.en: Then Bhadraka the village chief went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn42.11:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desetū”ti.
sn42.11:1.3.ref: “Please, sir, let the Blessed One teach me the origin and cessation of suffering.”
sn42.11:1.3.en: “Please, sir, let the Blessed One teach me the origin and cessation of suffering.”

sn42.11:1.4.pli: “Ahañce te, gāmaṇi, atītamaddhānaṁ ārabbha dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca deseyyaṁ:
sn42.11:1.4.ref: “Chief, if I were to teach you about the origin and disappearance of suffering in the past, saying
sn42.11:1.4.en: “Chief, if I were to teach you about the origin and disappearance of suffering in the past, saying

sn42.11:1.5.pli: ‘evaṁ ahosi atītamaddhānan’ti, tatra te siyā kaṅkhā, siyā vimati.
sn42.11:1.5.ref: ‘this is how it was in the past,’ you might have doubts or uncertainties about that.
sn42.11:1.5.en: ‘this is how it was in the past,’ you might have doubts or uncertainties about that.

sn42.11:1.6.pli: Ahañce te, gāmaṇi, anāgatamaddhānaṁ ārabbha dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca deseyyaṁ:
sn42.11:1.6.ref: If I were to teach you about the origin and disappearance of suffering in the future, saying
sn42.11:1.6.en: If I were to teach you about the origin and disappearance of suffering in the future, saying

sn42.11:1.7.pli: ‘evaṁ bhavissati anāgatamaddhānan’ti, tatrāpi te siyā kaṅkhā, siyā vimati.
sn42.11:1.7.ref: ‘this is how it will be in the future,’ you might have doubts or uncertainties about that.
sn42.11:1.7.en: ‘this is how it will be in the future,’ you might have doubts or uncertainties about that.

sn42.11:1.8.pli: Api cāhaṁ, gāmaṇi, idheva nisinno ettheva te nisinnassa dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desessāmi.
sn42.11:1.8.ref: Rather, chief, I will teach you about the origin and disappearance of suffering as I am sitting right here and you are sitting right there.
sn42.11:1.8.en: Rather, chief, I will teach you about the origin and disappearance of suffering as I am sitting right here and you are sitting right there.

sn42.11:1.9.pli: Taṁ suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn42.11:1.9.ref: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
sn42.11:1.9.en: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn42.11:1.10.pli: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho bhadrako gāmaṇi bhagavato paccassosi.

sn42.11:2.2.pli: atthi te uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn42.11:2.2.ref: Are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn42.11:2.2.en: Are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

sn42.11:2.3.pli: “Atthi me, bhante, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ me vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.

sn42.11:2.4.pli: “Atthi pana te, gāmaṇi, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn42.11:2.4.ref: “But are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would not cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn42.11:2.4.en: “But are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would not cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

sn42.11:2.5.pli: “Atthi me, bhante, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ me vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.

sn42.11:2.6.pli: “Ko nu kho, gāmaṇi, hetu, ko paccayo yena te ekaccānaṁ uruvelakappiyānaṁ manussānaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn42.11:2.6.ref: “What’s the cause, chief, what’s the reason why, if this was to happen to some people it could cause you sorrow, while if it happens to others it does not?”
sn42.11:2.6.en: “What’s the cause, chief, what’s the reason why, if this was to happen to some people it could cause you sorrow, while if it happens to others it does not?”

sn42.11:2.7.pli: “Yesaṁ me, bhante, uruvelakappiyānaṁ manussānaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā, atthi me tesu chandarāgo.
sn42.11:2.7.ref: “The people regarding whom this would give rise to sorrow are those I have desire and passion.
sn42.11:2.7.en: “The people regarding whom this would give rise to sorrow are those I have desire and passion.

sn42.11:2.8.pli: Yesaṁ pana, bhante, uruvelakappiyānaṁ manussānaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā, natthi me tesu chandarāgo”ti.
sn42.11:2.8.ref: The people regarding whom this would not give rise to sorrow are those I don’t have desire and passion.”
sn42.11:2.8.en: The people regarding whom this would not give rise to sorrow are those I don’t have desire and passion.”

sn42.11:2.9.pli: “Iminā tvaṁ, gāmaṇi, dhammena diṭṭhena viditena akālikena pattena pariyogāḷhena atītānāgate nayaṁ nehi:
sn42.11:2.9.ref: “With this present phenomenon that you have seen, understood, immediately attained, and fathomed, you can apply the same method to the past and future:
sn42.11:2.9.en: “With this present phenomenon that you have seen, understood, immediately attained, and fathomed, you can apply the same method to the past and future:

sn42.11:2.10.pli: ‘yaṁ kho kiñci atītamaddhānaṁ dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajji sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
sn42.11:2.10.ref: ‘All the suffering that arose in the past was rooted and sourced in desire.
sn42.11:2.10.en: ‘All the suffering that arose in the past was rooted and sourced in desire.

sn42.11:2.11.ref: For desire is the root of suffering.
sn42.11:2.11.en: For desire is the root of suffering.

sn42.11:2.12.pli: Yampi hi kiñci anāgatamaddhānaṁ dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjissati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
sn42.11:2.12.ref: All the suffering that will arise in the future will be rooted and sourced in desire.
sn42.11:2.12.en: All the suffering that will arise in the future will be rooted and sourced in desire.

sn42.11:2.13.ref: For desire is the root of suffering.’”
sn42.11:2.13.en: For desire is the root of suffering.’”

sn42.11:2.15.ref: How well said this was by the Buddha!
sn42.11:2.15.en: How well said this was by the Buddha!

sn42.11:2.16.pli: ‘yaṁ kiñci dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
sn42.11:2.16.ref: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.
sn42.11:2.16.en: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.

sn42.11:2.17.ref: For desire is the root of suffering.’
sn42.11:2.17.en: For desire is the root of suffering.’

sn42.11:2.18.pli: Atthi me, bhante, ciravāsī nāma kumāro bahi āvasathe paṭivasati.
sn42.11:2.18.ref: I have a boy called Ciravāsi, who resides in a house away from here.
sn42.11:2.18.en: I have a boy called Ciravāsi, who resides in a house away from here.

sn42.11:2.19.pli: So khvāhaṁ, bhante, kālasseva vuṭṭhāya purisaṁ uyyojemi:
sn42.11:2.19.ref: I rise early and dispatch someone, saying:
sn42.11:2.19.en: I rise early and dispatch someone, saying:

sn42.11:2.20.ref: ‘Go, my man, and check on my boy Ciravāsi.’
sn42.11:2.20.en: ‘Go, my man, and check on my boy Ciravāsi.’

sn42.11:2.21.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhante, so puriso nāgacchati, tassa me hoteva aññathattaṁ:
sn42.11:2.21.ref: Until they get back I worry:
sn42.11:2.21.en: Until they get back I worry:

sn42.11:3.2.pli: ciravāsissa kumārassa vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn42.11:3.2.ref: If Ciravāsi was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn42.11:3.2.en: If Ciravāsi was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

sn42.11:3.3.pli: “Ciravāsissa me, bhante, kumārassa vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṁ, kiṁ pana me nuppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.

sn42.11:3.4.ref: “This too is a way to understand:
sn42.11:3.4.en: “This too is a way to understand:

sn42.11:3.5.pli: ‘yaṁ kiñci dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
sn42.11:3.5.ref: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.
sn42.11:3.5.en: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.

sn42.11:3.6.ref: For desire is the root of suffering.’
sn42.11:3.6.en: For desire is the root of suffering.’

sn42.11:4.2.pli: yadā te ciravāsimātā adiṭṭhā ahosi, assutā ahosi, te ciravāsimātuyā chando vā rāgo vā pemaṁ vā”ti?
sn42.11:4.2.ref: Before you’d seen or heard of Ciravāsi’s mother, did you have any desire or passion or fondness for her?”
sn42.11:4.2.en: Before you’d seen or heard of Ciravāsi’s mother, did you have any desire or passion or fondness for her?”

sn42.11:4.4.pli: “Dassanaṁ vā te, gāmaṇi, āgamma savanaṁ vā evaṁ te ahosi:
sn42.11:4.4.ref: “Then was it because you saw or heard of her that you had
sn42.11:4.4.en: “Then was it because you saw or heard of her that you had

sn42.11:4.5.pli: ‘ciravāsimātuyā chando vā rāgo vā pemaṁ vā’”ti?
sn42.11:4.5.ref: desire or passion or fondness for her?”
sn42.11:4.5.en: desire or passion or fondness for her?”

sn42.11:5.2.pli: ciravāsimātuyā te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn42.11:5.2.ref: If Ciravāsi’s mother was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn42.11:5.2.en: If Ciravāsi’s mother was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

sn42.11:5.3.pli: “Ciravāsimātuyā me, bhante, vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṁ, kiṁ pana me nuppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.

sn42.11:5.4.ref: “This too is a way to understand:
sn42.11:5.4.en: “This too is a way to understand:

sn42.11:5.5.pli: ‘yaṁ kiñci dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
sn42.11:5.5.ref: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.
sn42.11:5.5.en: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.

sn42.11:5.6.ref: For desire is the root of suffering.’”
sn42.11:5.6.en: For desire is the root of suffering.’”

mn105:1.2.pli: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā vesāliyaṁ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṁ.
mn105:1.2.ref: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
mn105:1.2.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

mn105:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulehi bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā hoti:
mn105:2.1.ref: Now at that time several mendicants had declared their enlightenment in the Buddha’s presence:
mn105:2.1.en: Now at that time several mendicants had declared their enlightenment in the Buddha’s presence:

mn105:2.2.pli: “‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmā”ti.
mn105:2.2.ref: “We understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”
mn105:2.2.en: “We understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

mn105:2.3.ref: Sunakkhatta the Licchavi heard about this.
mn105:2.3.en: Sunakkhatta the Licchavi heard about this.

mn105:2.4.pli: “sambahulehi kira bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā hoti:

mn105:2.5.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyāti pajānāmā’”ti.

mn105:3.1.pli: Atha kho sunakkhatto licchaviputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho sunakkhatto licchaviputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
mn105:3.1.ref: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
mn105:3.1.en: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

mn105:4.2.pli: ‘sambahulehi kira bhikkhūhi bhagavato santike aññā byākatā—
mn105:4.2.ref: several mendicants have declared their enlightenment in the Buddha’s presence.
mn105:4.2.en: several mendicants have declared their enlightenment in the Buddha’s presence.

mn105:4.3.pli: khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyāti pajānāmā’ti.

mn105:4.4.pli: Ye te, bhante, bhikkhū bhagavato santike aññaṁ byākaṁsu:

mn105:4.5.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyāti pajānāmā’ti, kacci te, bhante, bhikkhū sammadeva aññaṁ byākaṁsu udāhu santetthekacce bhikkhū adhimānena aññaṁ byākaṁsū”ti?
mn105:4.5.ref: I trust they did so rightly—or are there some who declared enlightenment out of overestimation?”
mn105:4.5.en: I trust they did so rightly—or are there some who declared enlightenment out of overestimation?”

mn105:5.1.pli: “Ye te, sunakkhatta, bhikkhū mama santike aññaṁ byākaṁsu:

mn105:5.2.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyāti pajānāmā’ti.

mn105:5.3.pli: Santetthekacce bhikkhū sammadeva aññaṁ byākaṁsu, santi panidhekacce bhikkhū adhimānenapi aññaṁ byākaṁsu.
mn105:5.3.ref: “Some of them did so rightly, Sunakkhatta, while others did so out of overestimation.
mn105:5.3.en: “Some of them did so rightly, Sunakkhatta, while others did so out of overestimation.

mn105:5.4.pli: Tatra, sunakkhatta, ye te bhikkhū sammadeva aññaṁ byākaṁsu tesaṁ taṁ tatheva hoti;
mn105:5.4.ref: Now, when mendicants declare enlightenment rightly, that is their truth.
mn105:5.4.en: Now, when mendicants declare enlightenment rightly, that is their truth.

mn105:5.5.pli: ye pana te bhikkhū adhimānena aññaṁ byākaṁsu tatra, sunakkhatta, tathāgatassa evaṁ hoti:
mn105:5.5.ref: But when mendicants declare enlightenment out of overestimation, the Realized One thinks:
mn105:5.5.en: But when mendicants declare enlightenment out of overestimation, the Realized One thinks:

mn105:5.8.ref: he should teach them the Dhamma,
mn105:5.8.en: he should teach them the Dhamma,

mn105:5.9.pli: Atha ca panidhekacce moghapurisā pañhaṁ abhisaṅkharitvā abhisaṅkharitvā tathāgataṁ upasaṅkamitvā pucchanti.
mn105:5.9.ref: but then certain futile men, having carefully planned a question, approach the Realized One and ask it,
mn105:5.9.en: but then certain futile men, having carefully planned a question, approach the Realized One and ask it,

mn105:5.10.pli: Tatra, sunakkhatta, yampi tathāgatassa evaṁ hoti:

mn105:6.1.ref: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
mn105:6.1.en: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

mn105:6.2.pli: yaṁ bhagavā dhammaṁ deseyya. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
mn105:6.2.ref: Let the Buddha teach the Dhamma. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
mn105:6.2.en: Let the Buddha teach the Dhamma. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

mn105:6.3.pli: “Tena hi, sunakkhatta, suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn105:6.3.ref: “Well then, Sunakkhatta, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
mn105:6.3.en: “Well then, Sunakkhatta, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn105:6.4.pli: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho sunakkhatto licchaviputto bhagavato paccassosi.

mn105:7.1.ref: “Sunakkhatta, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
mn105:7.1.en: “Sunakkhatta, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn105:7.3.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā,
mn105:7.3.ref: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
mn105:7.3.en: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn105:7.7.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā—
mn105:7.7.ref: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
mn105:7.7.en: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn105:7.8.ref: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
mn105:7.8.en: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn105:8.1.pli: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṁ idhekacco purisapuggalo lokāmisādhimutto assa.
mn105:8.1.ref: It’s possible that a certain individual person may be intent on worldly pleasures of the flesh.
mn105:8.1.en: It’s possible that a certain individual person may be intent on worldly pleasures of the flesh.

mn105:8.2.pli: Lokāmisādhimuttassa kho, sunakkhatta, purisapuggalassa tappatirūpī ceva kathā saṇṭhāti, tadanudhammañca anuvitakketi, anuvicāreti, tañca purisaṁ bhajati, tena ca vittiṁ āpajjati;
mn105:8.2.ref: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it rewarding.
mn105:8.2.en: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it rewarding.

mn105:8.3.pli: āneñjapaṭisaṁyuttāya ca pana kathāya kacchamānāya na sussūsati, na sotaṁ odahati, na aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhāpeti, na ca taṁ purisaṁ bhajati, na ca tena vittiṁ āpajjati.
mn105:8.3.ref: But when talk connected with the imperturbable is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it rewarding.
mn105:8.3.en: But when talk connected with the imperturbable is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it rewarding.

mn105:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, puriso sakamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā ciravippavuttho assa.
mn105:9.1.ref: Suppose a person had left their own village or town long ago,
mn105:9.1.en: Suppose a person had left their own village or town long ago,

mn105:9.2.pli: So aññataraṁ purisaṁ passeyya tamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā acirapakkantaṁ.
mn105:9.2.ref: and they saw another person who had only recently left there.
mn105:9.2.en: and they saw another person who had only recently left there.

mn105:9.3.pli: So taṁ purisaṁ tassa gāmassa vā nigamassa vā khematañca subhikkhatañca appābādhatañca puccheyya;
mn105:9.3.ref: They would ask about whether their village was safe, with plenty of food and little disease,
mn105:9.3.en: They would ask about whether their village was safe, with plenty of food and little disease,

mn105:9.4.pli: tassa so puriso tassa gāmassa vā nigamassa vā khematañca subhikkhatañca appābādhatañca saṁseyya.
mn105:9.4.ref: and the other person would tell them the news.
mn105:9.4.en: and the other person would tell them the news.

mn105:9.10.pli: āneñjapaṭisaṁyuttāya ca pana kathāya kacchamānāya na sussūsati, na sotaṁ odahati, na aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhāpeti, na ca taṁ purisaṁ bhajati, na ca tena vittiṁ āpajjati.
mn105:9.10.ref: But when talk connected with the imperturbable is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it rewarding.

mn105:17.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, tālo matthakacchinno abhabbo puna viruḷhiyā;
mn105:17.1.ref: Suppose there was a palm tree with its crown cut off. It’s incapable of further growth.
mn105:17.1.en: Suppose there was a palm tree with its crown cut off. It’s incapable of further growth.

mn105:17.2.pli: evameva kho, sunakkhatta, sammā nibbānādhimuttassa purisapuggalassa ye nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaṁyojane se ucchinnamūle tālāvatthukate anabhāvaṅkate āyatiṁ anuppādadhamme.
mn105:17.2.ref: In the same way, an individual rightly intent on extinguishment has cut off the connection with the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
mn105:17.2.en: In the same way, an individual rightly intent on extinguishment has cut off the connection with the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

mn105:17.4.pli: ‘nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaṁyojanena hi kho visaṁyutto sammā nibbānādhimutto purisapuggalo’ti.
mn105:17.4.ref: ‘That individual is rightly intent on extinguishment, for they’re detached from things connected with the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’
mn105:17.4.en: ‘That individual is rightly intent on extinguishment, for they’re detached from things connected with the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

mn105:18.1.pli: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṁ idhekaccassa bhikkhuno evamassa:
mn105:18.1.ref: It’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:
mn105:18.1.en: It’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:

mn105:18.2.pli: ‘taṇhā kho sallaṁ samaṇena vuttaṁ, avijjāvisadoso, chandarāgabyāpādena ruppati.
mn105:18.2.ref: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.
mn105:18.2.en: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.

mn105:18.3.pli: Taṁ me taṇhāsallaṁ pahīnaṁ, apanīto avijjāvisadoso, sammā nibbānādhimuttohamasmī’ti.
mn105:18.3.ref: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’
mn105:18.3.en: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’

mn105:18.4.ref: Having such conceit, though it’s not based in fact,
mn105:18.4.en: Having such conceit, though it’s not based in fact,

mn105:18.5.pli: So yāni sammā nibbānādhimuttassa asappāyāni tāni anuyuñjeyya; asappāyaṁ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṁ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ sotena saddaṁ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ ghānena gandhaṁ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ jivhāya rasaṁ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ manasā dhammaṁ anuyuñjeyya.
mn105:18.5.ref: they would engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.
mn105:18.5.en: they would engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

mn105:18.6.pli: Tassa asappāyaṁ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṁ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ sotena saddaṁ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ ghānena gandhaṁ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ jivhāya rasaṁ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ manasā dhammaṁ anuyuttassa rāgo cittaṁ anuddhaṁseyya.
mn105:18.6.ref: Doing so, lust infects their mind,
mn105:18.6.en: Doing so, lust infects their mind,

mn105:18.7.pli: So rāgānuddhaṁsitena cittena maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ.
mn105:18.7.ref: resulting in death or deadly pain.
mn105:18.7.en: resulting in death or deadly pain.

mn105:19.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, puriso sallena viddho assa savisena gāḷhūpalepanena.
mn105:19.1.ref: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison.
mn105:19.1.en: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison.

mn105:19.2.pli: Tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṁ sallakattaṁ upaṭṭhāpeyyuṁ.
mn105:19.2.ref: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.
mn105:19.2.en: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.

mn105:19.3.pli: Tassa so bhisakko sallakatto satthena vaṇamukhaṁ parikanteyya.
mn105:19.3.ref: The surgeon would cut open the wound with a scalpel,
mn105:19.3.en: The surgeon would cut open the wound with a scalpel,

mn105:19.4.pli: Satthena vaṇamukhaṁ parikantitvā esaniyā sallaṁ eseyya.

mn105:19.5.pli: Esaniyā sallaṁ esitvā sallaṁ abbuheyya, apaneyya visadosaṁ saupādisesaṁ.
mn105:19.5.ref: extract it, and expel the poison, leaving some residue behind.
mn105:19.5.en: extract it, and expel the poison, leaving some residue behind.

mn105:19.6.ref: Imagining that no residue remained, the surgeon would say:
mn105:19.6.en: Imagining that no residue remained, the surgeon would say:

mn105:19.7.pli: ‘ambho purisa, ubbhataṁ kho te sallaṁ, apanīto visadoso saupādiseso.
mn105:19.7.ref: ‘My good man, the dart has been extracted and the poison expelled without residue.
mn105:19.7.en: ‘My good man, the dart has been extracted and the poison expelled without residue.

mn105:19.8.ref: It is still capable of harming you.
mn105:19.8.en: It is still capable of harming you.

mn105:19.9.pli: Sappāyāni ceva bhojanāni bhuñjeyyāsi, mā te asappāyāni bhojanāni bhuñjato vaṇo assāvī assa.
mn105:19.9.ref: Eat only suitable food. Don’t eat unsuitable food, or else the wound may get infected.
mn105:19.9.en: Eat only suitable food. Don’t eat unsuitable food, or else the wound may get infected.

mn105:19.10.pli: Kālena kālañca vaṇaṁ dhoveyyāsi, kālena kālaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ ālimpeyyāsi, mā te na kālena kālaṁ vaṇaṁ dhovato na kālena kālaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ ālimpato pubbalohitaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ pariyonandhi.
mn105:19.10.ref: Regularly wash the wound and anoint the opening, or else it’ll get covered with pus and blood.
mn105:19.10.en: Regularly wash the wound and anoint the opening, or else it’ll get covered with pus and blood.

mn105:19.11.pli: Mā ca vātātape cārittaṁ anuyuñji, mā te vātātape cārittaṁ anuyuttassa rajosūkaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ anuddhaṁsesi.
mn105:19.11.ref: Don’t walk too much in the wind and sun, or else dust and dirt will infect the wound.
mn105:19.11.en: Don’t walk too much in the wind and sun, or else dust and dirt will infect the wound.

mn105:19.12.pli: Vaṇānurakkhī ca, ambho purisa, vihareyyāsi vaṇasāropī’ti.
mn105:19.12.ref: Take care of the wound, my good fellow, heal it.’
mn105:19.12.en: Take care of the wound, my good fellow, heal it.’

mn105:20.2.pli: ‘ubbhataṁ kho me sallaṁ, apanīto visadoso anupādiseso.
mn105:20.2.ref: ‘The dart has been extracted and the poison expelled with no residue.
mn105:20.2.en: ‘The dart has been extracted and the poison expelled with no residue.

mn105:20.3.ref: It’s not capable of harming me.’
mn105:20.3.en: It’s not capable of harming me.’

mn105:20.4.pli: So asappāyāni ceva bhojanāni bhuñjeyya. Tassa asappāyāni bhojanāni bhuñjato vaṇo assāvī assa.
mn105:20.4.ref: They’d eat unsuitable food, and the wound would get infected.
mn105:20.4.en: They’d eat unsuitable food, and the wound would get infected.

mn105:20.5.pli: Na ca kālena kālaṁ vaṇaṁ dhoveyya, na ca kālena kālaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ ālimpeyya. Tassa na kālena kālaṁ vaṇaṁ dhovato, na kālena kālaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ ālimpato pubbalohitaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ pariyonandheyya.
mn105:20.5.ref: And they wouldn’t regularly wash and anoint the opening, so it would get covered in pus and blood.
mn105:20.5.en: And they wouldn’t regularly wash and anoint the opening, so it would get covered in pus and blood.

mn105:20.6.pli: Vātātape ca cārittaṁ anuyuñjeyya. Tassa vātātape cārittaṁ anuyuttassa rajosūkaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ anuddhaṁseyya.
mn105:20.6.ref: And they’d walk too much in the wind and sun, so dust and dirt infected the wound.
mn105:20.6.en: And they’d walk too much in the wind and sun, so dust and dirt infected the wound.

mn105:20.7.pli: Na ca vaṇānurakkhī vihareyya na vaṇasāropī.
mn105:20.7.ref: And they wouldn’t take care of the wound or heal it.
mn105:20.7.en: And they wouldn’t take care of the wound or heal it.

mn105:20.8.pli: Tassa imissā ca asappāyakiriyāya, asuci visadoso apanīto saupādiseso tadubhayena vaṇo puthuttaṁ gaccheyya.
mn105:20.8.ref: Then both because they did what was unsuitable, and because of the residue of unclean poison, the wound would expand,
mn105:20.8.en: Then both because they did what was unsuitable, and because of the residue of unclean poison, the wound would expand,

mn105:20.9.pli: So puthuttaṁ gatena vaṇena maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ.
mn105:20.9.ref: resulting in death or deadly pain.
mn105:20.9.en: resulting in death or deadly pain.

mn105:21.4.ref: Having such conceit, though it’s not based in fact,
mn105:21.4.en: Having such conceit, though it’s not based in fact,

mn105:21.5.pli: So yāni sammā nibbānādhimuttassa asappāyāni tāni anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṁ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ sotena saddaṁ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ ghānena gandhaṁ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ jivhāya rasaṁ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ anuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ manasā dhammaṁ anuyuñjeyya.
mn105:21.5.ref: they would engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.
mn105:21.5.en: they would engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

mn105:21.6.pli: Tassa asappāyaṁ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṁ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ sotena saddaṁ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ ghānena gandhaṁ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ jivhāya rasaṁ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ anuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ manasā dhammaṁ anuyuttassa rāgo cittaṁ anuddhaṁseyya.
mn105:21.6.ref: Doing so, lust infects their mind,
mn105:21.6.en: Doing so, lust infects their mind,

mn105:21.7.pli: So rāgānuddhaṁsitena cittena maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ.
mn105:21.7.ref: resulting in death or deadly pain.
mn105:21.7.en: resulting in death or deadly pain.

mn105:22.1.pli: Maraṇañhetaṁ, sunakkhatta, ariyassa vinaye yo sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati;
mn105:22.1.ref: For it is death in the training of the Noble One to disavow the training and return to a lesser life.
mn105:22.1.en: For it is death in the training of the Noble One to disavow the training and return to a lesser life.

mn105:22.2.pli: maraṇamattañhetaṁ, sunakkhatta, dukkhaṁ yaṁ aññataraṁ saṅkiliṭṭhaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjati.
mn105:22.2.ref: And it is deadly pain to commit one of the corrupt offenses.
mn105:22.2.en: And it is deadly pain to commit one of the corrupt offenses.

mn105:23.1.pli: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṁ idhekaccassa bhikkhuno evamassa:
mn105:23.1.ref: It’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:
mn105:23.1.en: It’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:

mn105:23.2.pli: ‘taṇhā kho sallaṁ samaṇena vuttaṁ, avijjāvisadoso chandarāgabyāpādena ruppati.
mn105:23.2.ref: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.
mn105:23.2.en: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.

mn105:23.3.pli: Taṁ me taṇhāsallaṁ pahīnaṁ, apanīto avijjāvisadoso, sammā nibbānādhimuttohamasmī’ti.
mn105:23.3.ref: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’
mn105:23.3.en: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’

mn105:23.4.pli: Sammā nibbānādhimuttasseva sato so yāni sammā nibbānādhimuttassa asappāyāni tāni nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṁ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ sotena saddaṁ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ ghānena gandhaṁ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ jivhāya rasaṁ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ manasā dhammaṁ nānuyuñjeyya.
mn105:23.4.ref: Being rightly intent on extinguishment, they wouldn’t engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.
mn105:23.4.en: Being rightly intent on extinguishment, they wouldn’t engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

mn105:23.5.pli: Tassa asappāyaṁ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṁ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ sotena saddaṁ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ ghānena gandhaṁ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ jivhāya rasaṁ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ manasā dhammaṁ nānuyuttassa rāgo cittaṁ nānuddhaṁseyya.
mn105:23.5.ref: Doing so, lust wouldn’t infect their mind,
mn105:23.5.en: Doing so, lust wouldn’t infect their mind,

mn105:23.6.pli: So na rāgānuddhaṁsitena cittena neva maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya na maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ.
mn105:23.6.ref: so no death or deadly pain would result.
mn105:23.6.en: so no death or deadly pain would result.

mn105:24.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, puriso sallena viddho assa savisena gāḷhūpalepanena.
mn105:24.1.ref: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison.
mn105:24.1.en: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison.

mn105:24.2.pli: Tassa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā bhisakkaṁ sallakattaṁ upaṭṭhāpeyyuṁ.
mn105:24.2.ref: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.
mn105:24.2.en: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.

mn105:24.3.pli: Tassa so bhisakko sallakatto satthena vaṇamukhaṁ parikanteyya.
mn105:24.3.ref: The surgeon would cut open the wound with a scalpel,
mn105:24.3.en: The surgeon would cut open the wound with a scalpel,

mn105:24.4.pli: Satthena vaṇamukhaṁ parikantitvā esaniyā sallaṁ eseyya.

mn105:24.5.pli: Esaniyā sallaṁ esitvā sallaṁ abbuheyya, apaneyya visadosaṁ anupādisesaṁ.
mn105:24.5.ref: extract it, and expel the poison, leaving no residue behind.
mn105:24.5.en: extract it, and expel the poison, leaving no residue behind.

mn105:24.6.ref: Knowing that no residue remained, the surgeon would say:
mn105:24.6.en: Knowing that no residue remained, the surgeon would say:

mn105:24.7.pli: ‘ambho purisa, ubbhataṁ kho te sallaṁ, apanīto visadoso anupādiseso.
mn105:24.7.ref: ‘My good man, the dart has been extracted and the poison expelled with no residue.
mn105:24.7.en: ‘My good man, the dart has been extracted and the poison expelled with no residue.

mn105:24.8.ref: It’s not capable of harming you.
mn105:24.8.en: It’s not capable of harming you.

mn105:24.9.pli: Sappāyāni ceva bhojanāni bhuñjeyyāsi, mā te asappāyāni bhojanāni bhuñjato vaṇo assāvī assa.
mn105:24.9.ref: Eat only suitable food. Don’t eat unsuitable food, or else the wound may get infected.
mn105:24.9.en: Eat only suitable food. Don’t eat unsuitable food, or else the wound may get infected.

mn105:24.10.pli: Kālena kālañca vaṇaṁ dhoveyyāsi, kālena kālaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ ālimpeyyāsi. Mā te na kālena kālaṁ vaṇaṁ dhovato na kālena kālaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ ālimpato pubbalohitaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ pariyonandhi.
mn105:24.10.ref: Regularly wash the wound and anoint the opening, or else it’ll get covered with pus and blood.
mn105:24.10.en: Regularly wash the wound and anoint the opening, or else it’ll get covered with pus and blood.

mn105:24.11.pli: Mā ca vātātape cārittaṁ anuyuñji, mā te vātātape cārittaṁ anuyuttassa rajosūkaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ anuddhaṁsesi.
mn105:24.11.ref: Don’t walk too much in the wind and sun, or else dust and dirt will infect the wound.
mn105:24.11.en: Don’t walk too much in the wind and sun, or else dust and dirt will infect the wound.

mn105:24.12.pli: Vaṇānurakkhī ca, ambho purisa, vihareyyāsi vaṇasāropī’ti.
mn105:24.12.ref: Take care of the wound, my good fellow, heal it.’
mn105:24.12.en: Take care of the wound, my good fellow, heal it.’

mn105:25.2.pli: ‘ubbhataṁ kho me sallaṁ, apanīto visadoso anupādiseso.
mn105:25.2.ref: ‘The dart has been extracted and the poison expelled with no residue.
mn105:25.2.en: ‘The dart has been extracted and the poison expelled with no residue.

mn105:25.3.ref: It’s not capable of harming me.’
mn105:25.3.en: It’s not capable of harming me.’

mn105:25.4.pli: So sappāyāni ceva bhojanāni bhuñjeyya. Tassa sappāyāni bhojanāni bhuñjato vaṇo na assāvī assa.
mn105:25.4.ref: They’d eat suitable food, and the wound wouldn’t get infected.
mn105:25.4.en: They’d eat suitable food, and the wound wouldn’t get infected.

mn105:25.5.pli: Kālena kālañca vaṇaṁ dhoveyya, kālena kālaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ ālimpeyya. Tassa kālena kālaṁ vaṇaṁ dhovato kālena kālaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ ālimpato na pubbalohitaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ pariyonandheyya.
mn105:25.5.ref: And they’d regularly wash and anoint the opening, so it wouldn’t get covered in pus and blood.
mn105:25.5.en: And they’d regularly wash and anoint the opening, so it wouldn’t get covered in pus and blood.

mn105:25.6.pli: Na ca vātātape cārittaṁ anuyuñjeyya. Tassa vātātape cārittaṁ ananuyuttassa rajosūkaṁ vaṇamukhaṁ nānuddhaṁseyya.
mn105:25.6.ref: And they wouldn’t walk too much in the wind and sun, so dust and dirt wouldn’t infect the wound.
mn105:25.6.en: And they wouldn’t walk too much in the wind and sun, so dust and dirt wouldn’t infect the wound.

mn105:25.7.ref: And they’d take care of the wound and heal it.
mn105:25.7.en: And they’d take care of the wound and heal it.

mn105:25.8.pli: Tassa imissā ca sappāyakiriyāya asu ca visadoso apanīto anupādiseso tadubhayena vaṇo viruheyya.
mn105:25.8.ref: Then both because they did what was suitable, and the unclean poison had left no residue, the wound would heal,
mn105:25.8.en: Then both because they did what was suitable, and the unclean poison had left no residue, the wound would heal,

mn105:25.9.pli: So ruḷhena vaṇena sañchavinā neva maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya na maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ.
mn105:25.9.ref: and no death or deadly pain would result.
mn105:25.9.en: and no death or deadly pain would result.

mn105:26.1.pli: Evameva kho, sunakkhatta, ṭhānametaṁ vijjati yaṁ idhekaccassa bhikkhuno evamassa:
mn105:26.1.ref: In the same way, it’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:
mn105:26.1.en: In the same way, it’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:

mn105:26.2.pli: ‘taṇhā kho sallaṁ samaṇena vuttaṁ, avijjāvisadoso chandarāgabyāpādena ruppati.
mn105:26.2.ref: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.
mn105:26.2.en: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.

mn105:26.3.pli: Taṁ me taṇhāsallaṁ pahīnaṁ, apanīto avijjāvisadoso, sammā nibbānādhimuttohamasmī’ti.
mn105:26.3.ref: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’
mn105:26.3.en: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’

mn105:26.4.pli: Sammā nibbānādhimuttasseva sato so yāni sammā nibbānādhimuttassa asappāyāni tāni nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṁ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ sotena saddaṁ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ ghānena gandhaṁ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ jivhāya rasaṁ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ nānuyuñjeyya, asappāyaṁ manasā dhammaṁ nānuyuñjeyya.
mn105:26.4.ref: Being rightly intent on extinguishment, they wouldn’t engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.
mn105:26.4.en: Being rightly intent on extinguishment, they wouldn’t engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

mn105:26.5.pli: Tassa asappāyaṁ cakkhunā rūpadassanaṁ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ sotena saddaṁ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ ghānena gandhaṁ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ jivhāya rasaṁ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ nānuyuttassa, asappāyaṁ manasā dhammaṁ nānuyuttassa, rāgo cittaṁ nānuddhaṁseyya.
mn105:26.5.ref: Doing so, lust wouldn’t infect their mind,
mn105:26.5.en: Doing so, lust wouldn’t infect their mind,

mn105:26.6.pli: So na rāgānuddhaṁsitena cittena neva maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya na maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ.
mn105:26.6.ref: so no death or deadly pain would result.
mn105:26.6.en: so no death or deadly pain would result.

mn105:27.1.pli: Upamā kho me ayaṁ, sunakkhatta, katā atthassa viññāpanāya.
mn105:27.1.ref: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
mn105:27.1.en: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.

mn105:27.3.pli: vaṇoti kho, sunakkhatta, channetaṁ ajjhattikānaṁ āyatanānaṁ adhivacanaṁ;
mn105:27.3.ref: ‘Wound’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.
mn105:27.3.en: ‘Wound’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.

mn105:27.7.pli: satthanti kho, sunakkhatta, ariyāyetaṁ paññāya adhivacanaṁ;
mn105:27.7.ref: ‘Scalpel’ is a term for noble wisdom.
mn105:27.7.en: ‘Scalpel’ is a term for noble wisdom.

mn105:27.8.pli: bhisakko sallakattoti kho, sunakkhatta, tathāgatassetaṁ adhivacanaṁ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
mn105:27.8.ref: ‘Surgeon’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
mn105:27.8.en: ‘Surgeon’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

mn105:28.1.pli: So vata, sunakkhatta, bhikkhu chasu phassāyatanesu saṁvutakārī.
mn105:28.1.ref: Truly, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact.
mn105:28.1.en: Truly, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact.

mn105:28.2.pli: ‘Upadhi dukkhassa mūlan’ti—iti viditvā nirupadhi upadhisaṅkhaye vimutto upadhismiṁ vā kāyaṁ upasaṁharissati cittaṁ vā uppādessatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
mn105:28.2.ref: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments. It’s not possible that they would apply their body or interest their mind in any attachment.
mn105:28.2.en: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments. It’s not possible that they would apply their body or interest their mind in any attachment.

mn105:29.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sunakkhatta, āpānīyakaṁso vaṇṇasampanno gandhasampanno rasasampanno;
mn105:29.1.ref: Suppose there was a bronze goblet of beverage that had a nice color, aroma, and flavor.
mn105:29.1.en: Suppose there was a bronze goblet of beverage that had a nice color, aroma, and flavor.

mn105:29.2.ref: But it was mixed with poison.
mn105:29.2.en: But it was mixed with poison.

mn105:29.3.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhapaṭikūlo.
mn105:29.3.ref: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.
mn105:29.3.en: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.

mn105:29.5.pli: api nu so puriso amuṁ āpānīyakaṁsaṁ piveyya yaṁ jaññā:
mn105:29.5.ref: Would that person drink that beverage if they knew that
mn105:29.5.en: Would that person drink that beverage if they knew that

mn105:29.6.pli: ‘imāhaṁ pivitvā maraṇaṁ vā nigacchāmi maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhan’”ti?
mn105:29.6.ref: it would result in death or deadly suffering?”
mn105:29.6.en: it would result in death or deadly suffering?”

mn105:29.8.pli: “Evameva kho, sunakkhatta, so vata bhikkhu chasu phassāyatanesu saṁvutakārī.
mn105:29.8.ref: “In the same way, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact.
mn105:29.8.en: “In the same way, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact.

mn105:29.9.pli: ‘Upadhi dukkhassa mūlan’ti—iti viditvā nirupadhi upadhisaṅkhaye vimutto upadhismiṁ vā kāyaṁ upasaṁharissati cittaṁ vā uppādessatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
mn105:29.9.ref: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments. It’s not possible that they would apply their body or interest their mind in any attachment.
mn105:29.9.en: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments. It’s not possible that they would apply their body or interest their mind in any attachment.

mn105:30.1.ref: Suppose there was a lethal viper.
mn105:30.1.en: Suppose there was a lethal viper.

mn105:30.2.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhapaṭikūlo.
mn105:30.2.ref: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.
mn105:30.2.en: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.

mn105:30.4.pli: api nu so puriso amussa āsīvisassa ghoravisassa hatthaṁ vā aṅguṭṭhaṁ vā dajjā yaṁ jaññā:
mn105:30.4.ref: Would that person give that lethal viper their hand or finger if they knew that
mn105:30.4.en: Would that person give that lethal viper their hand or finger if they knew that

mn105:30.5.pli: ‘imināhaṁ daṭṭho maraṇaṁ vā nigacchāmi maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhan’”ti?
mn105:30.5.ref: it would result in death or deadly suffering?”
mn105:30.5.en: it would result in death or deadly suffering?”

mn105:30.7.pli: “Evameva kho, sunakkhatta, so vata bhikkhu chasu phassāyatanesu saṁvutakārī.
mn105:30.7.ref: “In the same way, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact.
mn105:30.7.en: “In the same way, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact.

mn105:30.8.pli: ‘Upadhi dukkhassa mūlan’ti—iti viditvā nirupadhi upadhisaṅkhaye vimutto upadhismiṁ vā kāyaṁ upasaṁharissati cittaṁ vā uppādessatīti—
mn105:30.8.ref: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments. It’s not possible that they would apply their body or interest their mind in any attachment.”
mn105:30.8.en: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments. It’s not possible that they would apply their body or interest their mind in any attachment.”

mn105:30.10.ref: That is what the Buddha said.
mn105:30.10.en: That is what the Buddha said.

mn105:30.11.pli: Attamano sunakkhatto licchaviputto bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.
mn105:30.11.ref: Satisfied, Sunakkhatta of the Licchavi clan approved what the Buddha said.
mn105:30.11.en: Satisfied, Sunakkhatta of the Licchavi clan approved what the Buddha said.

mn1:1.2.pli: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā ukkaṭṭhāyaṁ viharati subhagavane sālarājamūle.
mn1:1.2.ref: At one time the Buddha was staying near Ukkaṭṭhā, in the Subhaga Forest at the root of a magnificent sal tree.
mn1:1.2.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Ukkaṭṭhā, in the Subhaga Forest at the root of a magnificent sal tree.

mn1:1.3.ref: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
mn1:1.3.en: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn1:2.1.ref: “Mendicants, I will teach you the explanation of the root of all things.
mn1:2.1.en: “Mendicants, I will teach you the explanation of the root of all things.

mn1:2.2.pli: Taṁ suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn1:2.2.ref: Listen and apply your minds well, I will speak.”
mn1:2.2.en: Listen and apply your minds well, I will speak.”

mn1:2.3.pli: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.

mn1:3.1.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṁ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṁ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto—
mn1:3.1.ref: “Take an unlearned ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.
mn1:3.1.en: “Take an unlearned ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.

mn1:3.3.pli: pathaviṁ pathavito saññatvā pathaviṁ maññati, pathaviyā maññati, pathavito maññati, pathaviṁ meti maññati, pathaviṁ abhinandati.
mn1:3.3.ref: Having perceived earth as earth, they conceive it to be earth, they conceive it in earth, they conceive it as earth, they conceive that ‘earth is mine’, they approve earth.
mn1:3.3.en: Having perceived earth as earth, they conceive it to be earth, they conceive it in earth, they conceive it as earth, they conceive that ‘earth is mine’, they approve earth.

mn1:3.5.ref: Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.
mn1:3.5.en: Because they haven’t completely understood it, I say.

mn1:4.2.pli: āpaṁ āpato saññatvā āpaṁ maññati, āpasmiṁ maññati, āpato maññati, āpaṁ meti maññati, āpaṁ abhinandati.
mn1:4.2.ref: Having perceived water as water, they conceive it to be water …
mn1:4.2.en: Having perceived water as water, they conceive it to be water …
